newsitem.title: CHINA: PRESS DIGEST-HK Newspaper Headlines - Aug 5.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-HK Newspaper Headlines - Aug 5.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Hong Kong press. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

-- SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- City University staff have been told to seek approval before giving interviews and offering manuscripts to books or journals. Failure to comply could lead to disciplinary or even legal action.

-- HONGKONG STANDARD -- Conflicts have erupted over the selection of test cases that would decide whether illegal immigrant children had the right of abode in Hong Kong, with several sample cases put forward by lawyers rejected by the Department of Justice.

-- MING PAO -- With Taiwan's national day holiday coming in two months, the Hong Kong government is hesitating to make laws banning Taiwan's "Republic of China" flags in Hong Kong public areas. Sources said that if Taiwan organisations and pro-Taiwan groups are willing to cooperate by keeping a low profile, the government might not resort to legislation.
-- WEN WEI PO -- Shanghai's Planning Committee experts said the city's per capita GDP would exceed US$3,000 within the year, while the city entered its post-industrial development stage.
-- TA KUNG PAO -- The first generation of Chinese light weaponry would be used first to equip the People's Liberation Army's Hong Kong garrison.
-- ECONOMIC TIMES -- U.S. department store Barney's and its creditors had accpeted the new acquisition offer of Dickson Concepts. Dickson would acquire 51 per cent in Barney's with HK$1 billion.

-- APPLE DAILY -- Striptease shows are becoming popular in China. In a park in Guangdong a temporary stage was erected where dancers stripped off to an audience including children. A ticket for such a two-hour show cost only HK$5.
